title: Hepburn Woods Walking Route

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Hepburn Wood
images.caption: Hepburn Wood From the ridge just above the wood which leads around to Chillingham Park.

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Cup & Ring marked boulder on Bewick Hill
images.caption: Cup & Ring marked boulder on the nearby Bewick Hill. This photograph shows the unusual horizontal line of cups carved on the vertical south face of the large cup and ring marked block. View is north showing Hepburn Wood on the steep western scarp below the moorland plateau.

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Above the forest at Hepburn Crags
images.caption: Above the forest at Hepburn Crags. View towards Chillingham Park

images.title: Track in Hepburn Wood by Russel Wills, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Track in Hepburn Wood

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Above the forest at Hepburn Crags
images.caption: Above the forest at Hepburn Crags

images.title: Bronze age burial cist and capstone by Ed Jennings, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bronze age burial cist and capstone in the woods.

images.title: Hepburn Moor by Ian Capper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hepburn Moor. The moor lies just to the east of the woods. You could follow footpaths onto the moor and enjoy the lovely heather in late summer.

images.title: Bracken and heather above Hepburn Wood by Russel Wills, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bracken and heather above Hepburn Wood

description: This walk visits Hepburn Woods in Northumberland. There's miles of peaceful woodland trails and some fine views from the adjacent Hepburn Crag. You can start your walk from the car park near to the crags and Ros Castle. From here there's trails to follow south into the woods. On the way you'll pass Bertheles stone, a large boulder that has at some time detached itself from the crags above. There's also an Iron Age Hill Fort and some pretty heather in the summer months. The crags are located just to the east of the start point for the walk. There's an Iron Age Hillfort here with lots of pretty heather during the summer months. From the elevated position of the area there are fine views towards the Cheviots .
